unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the difference between "www" and just directly typing a website name, right? It's a good question!
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about the difference between "W-W-W" and just directly typing a website name, right? It's a good question!

unnormalised: See, back in the day, like early internet times, "www" was super important. It stood for "World Wide Web," and it was basically telling the server that you wanted to access the website's content specifically, and not, say, its email or other services. Think of it like telling the auto-rickshaw driver exactly where you want to go within a complex building - you wouldn’t just say “that building”, you would be specific, right?
normalised: See, back in the day, like early internet times, "W-W-W" was super important. It stood for "World Wide Web," and it was basically telling the server that you wanted to access the website's content specifically, and not, say, its email or other services. Think of it like telling the auto-rickshaw driver exactly where you want to go within a complex building - you wouldn’t just say “that building”, you would be specific, right?

unnormalised: But these days? Most modern browsers, like Chrome or Firefox (or even JioPages!), they're smart. They automatically assume you want the "www" part, so they add it for you even if you don't type it. It's like they've already prepone'd the auto-rickshaw ride for you! So, typing "google.com" is generally the same as typing "www.google.com".
normalised: But these days? Most modern browsers, like Chrome or Firefox (or even JioPages!), they're smart. They automatically assume you want the "W-W-W" part, so they add it for you even if you don't type it. It's like they've already preponed the auto-rickshaw ride for you! So, typing "google dot com" is generally the same as typing "W-W-W dot google dot com".

unnormalised: There *can* be some exceptions, though. Very rarely, a website might be set up in a way that only works with or without the "www". Sometimes, old websites, especially ones that haven’t been updated since, say, '95 or '96 (I'm just guessing!), might have weird configurations.
normalised: There can be some exceptions, though. Very rarely, a website might be set up in a way that only works with or without the "W-W-W". Sometimes, old websites, especially ones that haven’t been updated since, say, ninety five or ninety six (I'm just guessing!), might have weird configurations.

unnormalised: And, if you're setting up your own website, you need to decide if you want your site to work with or without the "www". It's something to consider when you're messing around with DNS settings, which honestly, is a headache if you're not familiar with it. My friend, Rohan, who works at TCS, helped me set up my blog, otherwise, I would have been totally lost.
normalised: And, if you're setting up your own website, you need to decide if you want your site to work with or without the "W-W-W". It's something to consider when you're messing around with D-N-S settings, which honestly, is a headache if you're not familiar with it. My friend, Rohan, who works at T-C-S, helped me set up my blog, otherwise, I would have been totally lost.

unnormalised: Also, remember HTTP vs. HTTPS? That's totally different. HTTPS is secure, HTTP isn't. Always look for the padlock icon in your browser to make sure the website is using HTTPS, especially when you're entering personal information or credit card details. Don't want anyone stealing your Diwali shopping budget, right? Nowadays, most websites use HTTPS by default, but it's still a good habit to check. Chrome usually indicates not secure HTTP website with a small tag.
normalised: Also, remember H-T-T-P versus H-T-T-P-S? That's totally different. H-T-T-P-S is secure, H-T-T-P isn't. Always look for the padlock icon in your browser to make sure the website is using H-T-T-P-S, especially when you're entering personal information or credit card details. Don't want anyone stealing your Diwali shopping budget, right? Nowadays, most websites use H-T-T-P-S by default, but it's still a good habit to check. Chrome usually indicates not secure H-T-T-P website with a small tag.

unnormalised: So, TL;DR (that's "too long; didn't read," btw): "www" is mostly optional now. But knowing where it came from and understanding how websites are set up is still a good thing! You never know when that random knowledge might come in handy.
normalised: So, T-L-D-R (that's "too long; didn't read," by the way): "W-W-W" is mostly optional now. But knowing where it came from and understanding how websites are set up is still a good thing! You never know when that random knowledge might come in handy.
